Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.

items.item_details:
By contracting with the State Chancellor's Office, the District may recover outstanding student debts owed such as enrollment fees and library fines.  Under the program, the State Chancellor's Office requests the Franchise Tax Board to offset (deduct) the amount owed to the District from the student's personal state income tax refund, lottery winnings, or other state refund.  The Franchise Tax Board remits any amounts offset to the State Chancellor's Office, which then authorizes the State Controller to disburse the offset amount, less a 25% administrative fee, to the District.
	 
The program is one of a multi-pronged approach to recover outstanding student debts.  The District sends emails to students throughout the term advising of their outstanding balance and providing options to satisfy their outstanding balance.  Upon completion of the term, students who still have an outstanding balance despite receiving emails during the term are sent a letter advising that the balance remains outstanding, that a hold remains on their account, the options available to them to satisfy their outstanding balance, and that failure to satisfy the outstanding debt within 30 days may result in their account being referred to an external collection agency.
	 
Last year, the District referred $2,583,024 in outstanding student debt and recovered $335,296.20 through the 2012 program.

items.item_details:
On the evening of Monday, June 11, 2012, Evergreen Valley College (EVC) experienced a power outage problem that affected the entire campus as well as parts of east San Jose. PG&E was immediately dispatched to assist with this problem. PG&E had informed the District that the cause was not linked to their services.
	 
The District promptly contacted Cupertino Electric, Inc. to assist with this issue. On this same evening, Cupertino Electric, Inc. and the District shut down all disconnects throughout EVC so that PG&E could re-energize the buildings on the morning of Tuesday, June 12, 2012. After doing so, Feeders 1 and 4 were re-energized, bringing back online several buildings and structures, however the remaining buildings and structures failed to come back online. Staff that worked in these building were either redirected to other facilities and departments or requested to go home until further notice. In the meantime, Cupertino Electric, Inc. continued to troubleshoot over the next couple of days to pinpoint the fault in Feeders 2 and 3, testing 15,000 feet of cable.
	 
On Thursday, June 14, 2012, Cupertino Electric, Inc. identified the damaged cable which was located between the portables and the center of the Cedro building. Cupertino Electric pulled over 600 feet of cable located 15 feet underground and uncovered a blown out cable. The cause of this blow out is unknown, however the cable was installed in 1983. The replacement cable was immediately placed on special order and delivered on Saturday, June 16, 2012. Cupertino Electric, Inc. then installed the new cable and conducted final tests to complete the distribution system. This was urgent because summer intersession was to start on Monday, June 18, 2012.
	 
To avoid a possible precursor to failure, this work continued into Saturday, June 30, 2012 and Sunday, July 1, 2012, working on three EVC buildings: Acacia, Roble and Cedro. This work included, but was not limited to, replacing fiberglass sheets, which is used as insulation materials, tested and repaired an indoor substation due to a transformer having a low resistance, etc.
	 
The District did not seek formal bids because this was an emergency that required immediate attention in order to secure the health and safety concern for our students, staff and faculty, as well as damage and danger to District property. Therefore, the District invoked California Public Contract Code Section 20654, which states, “In an emergency when any repairs, alterations, work or improvements is necessary to any facility of the college, or to permit the continuance of existing college classes, or to avoid danger to life or property, the board may by unanimous vote, with the approval of the county superintendent of schools … make a contract in writing or otherwise on behalf of the district for the performance of labor and furnishing of materials or supplies for the purpose without advertising for or inviting bids.” The District received approval from Mr. Kenneth Shelton, Chief Business Officer of Santa Clara County Office of Education, acting on behalf of Dr. Charles Weis, Santa Clara County Superintendent of Schools. 
	 
Therefore, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees unanimously approve and award the contract to Cupertino Electric, Inc. in the amount of $149,784.91 for the emergency work due to the EVC power outage “without advertising for or inviting bids” “to avoid the danger of life and property.”

Contracts
Design Professional Agreements for Measure G-2010 Projects
	 
In keeping with the updated Master Plan approved by the Board in November 2011, the District issued Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for professional design services to perform various specialty assignments under direct contract to the District on a work-order basis for various Measure G-2010 projects.  Outreach efforts included posting to the District Purchasing website and direct contact by e-mail and phone to minority and woman-owned small disadvantaged businesses.
	 
On February 16 and March 15, 2012 the District received Statements of Qualifications (SOQ) in response to the RFQ.  A District Review Panel consisting of representatives from the District and each college reviewed each SOQ, discussed the merits and ranked each firm.  From those rankings, the Review Panel selected the firms to be offered Master Agreements for Professional Services related to Measure G-2010 projects for the following disciplines:
	 
Architectural (Fees under $300,000)
Structural Engineering
Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing Engineering
Interior Space Planning (design)
	 
The Board is asked to approve the selection of the firms listed in each group (see attachment) for issuance of a Master Agreement for Professional Services in their specialty for Measure G-2010 projects.
	 
Consultant Selections for Measure G-2010 Projects
	 
In keeping with the updated Master Plan approved by the Board in November 2011, the District issued Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for Professional Services to perform various tasks under direct contract to the District on a work-order basis for various Measure G-2010 projects.  Outreach efforts included posting to the District Purchasing website and direct contact by e-mail and phone to minority and woman-owned small disadvantaged businesses.
	 
On February 16 and March 15, 2012 the District received Statements of Qualifications (SOQ) in response to the RFQ.  A District Review Panel consisting of representatives from the District and each college reviewed each SOQ, discussed the merits and ranked each firm.  From those rankings, the Review Panel selected the firms deemed most qualified to provide certain services related to Measure G-2010 projects.  As specific tasks and work orders are identified, an approved firm would receive a project-specific Consultant Agreement appropriate to their work.  These professional consulting services are as follows:
	 
Topographic / Land Surveying
Geotechnical Engineer
Inspection Services (Inspector of Record - DSA)
Special Testing and Inspection
Commissioning
Hazardous Materials
	 
The Board is asked to approve the selection of the firms listed in each group (see attachment) as pre-approved for their area of professional expertise on Measure G-2010 projects.
	 
Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) – Salas O’Brien - SJCC Phase 1 – Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing and Fire Protection Upgrade Project
	 
Through the RFQ process a pool was established for Mechanical / Electrical / Plumbing (MEP) engineering services related to Measure G-2010 projects.  Based on the firm’s extensive knowledge of the campus and its systems, San Jose City College requested a proposal from Salas O’Brien to evaluate specific MEP system issues at the college and develop projects to address identified deficiencies.  Based on evaluation and negotiation of that proposal, Salas O’Brien was selected to provide this service.  
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a PAA to Salas O’Brien in the amount of $54,000 for the SJCC Phase 1- Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing and Fire Protection Upgrade Project.
	 
Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) – Salas O’Brien - Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings
	 
Through the RFQ process a pool was established for Mechanical / Electrical / Plumbing (MEP) engineering services related to Measure G-2010 projects.  Based on the firm’s extensive knowledge and previous design services related to various buildings on campus, most especially the Central Energy Plant, San Jose City College requested a proposal from Salas O’Brien to design necessary upgrades and new MEP services from the campus central MEP system to specific buildings.  Based on evaluation and negotiation of that proposal, Salas O’Brien was selected to provide this service.  
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a PAA to Salas O’Brien in the amount of $42,580 for Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings at SJCC.
	 
Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) – HMC Architects - Design Services for EVC South Campus Development (Lease/Leaseback Delivery Method)
	 
Based on a proposal and interview competition, HMC Architects was selected and approved by the Board to provide programming design services for the South Campus Development at EVC.  Subsequent to that award, the Board approved use of the lease/leaseback delivery method for the project.  EVC has been very satisfied with the effort by HMC and asked for a proposal to extend its design services to include full design services (including DSA coordination, construction administration and closeout) for the project.  The proposal was reviewed and subsequently negotiated for scope and cost as reflected by the PAA.
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a PAA for design and construction phase services on the EVC South Campus Development Project to HMC Architects in the amount of $3,575,000.
	 
Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) – Meyer Silberberg Landscape Architects – EVC Landscape Programming and Assessment Services
	 
Subsequent to approval by the Board on March 13, 2012 of four firms to provide landscape services related to Measure G-2010 projects, those four firms were asked to submit supplemental information related to providing evaluation, assessment and programming of the entire campus conditions looking toward the 2025 Facilities Master Plan.  Meyer Silberberg was selected by the college to submit a scope and cost proposal which has been reviewed and subsequently negotiated as reflected by the PAA.
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a PAA to Meyer Silberberg Land Architects for Landscape Programming and Assessment Services at EVC in the amount of $322,770.
	 
Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) – Salas O’Brien - EVC Phase 1 – Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing and Fire Protection Upgrade Project
	 
Through the RFQ process a pool was established for Mechanical / Electrical / Plumbing (MEP) engineering services related to Measure G-2010 projects.  Based on the firm’s extensive knowledge of the campus and its systems, Evergreen Valley College requested a proposal from Salas O’Brien to evaluate specific MEP system issues at the college and develop projects to address identified deficiencies.  Based on evaluation and negotiation of that proposal, Salas O’Brien was selected to provide this service.  
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a PAA to Salas O’Brien in the amount of $70,000 for EVC Phase 1 – Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing and Fire Protection Upgrade Project.
	 
Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) – Salas O’Brien – EVC Phase 1 - 21 kV Electrical Upgrade Project
	 
On June 11, 2012 Evergreen Valley College experienced a serious failure to its primary electrical system.  This caused six days of near campus-wide power outage as Maintenance staff worked to resolve the issue.  Based on the investigation of the failure it was found that there are many concerns about the entire system’s age and ability to safely provide consistent power throughout the campus.
	 
During the outage it was necessary to bring in firms with the right knowledge and experience to directly and expediently identify and resolve the problem.  Salas O’Brien has extensive knowledge of EVC and its systems, and it was during its response effort to the campus outage that other areas of concern were found.  This work is considered critical due to the potential impacts to health and safety on the campus.  
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a PAA to Salas O’Brien in the amount of $180,000 for the EVC Phase 1 - 21 kV Electrical Upgrade Project.
	 
	 
Contract Revisions and Changes 
Revision #001- Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architecture - SJCC Track & Field
	 
This revision in the amount of $5,330 includes professional design fees as requested by the College to provide design and construction administration for new goal posts and scoreboard, and GMAX and drainage percolation testing for the football field at SJCC.  The original agreement amount is $23,200.  The new contract value including this revision will be $28,530. 
	 
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a professional service revision to Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architecture in the amount of $5,330 for additional services related to the SJCC Track & Field Project.
	 
Prime Contract Change Order #001 – OC Jones & Sons Inc. - SJCC Track & Field
	 
Through a certified testing agency, it was determined that the existing athletic turf was not required to be disposed of at a Class 1 hazardous landfill, resulting in a savings / credit to the District in the amount of ($41,000).  Also included in this change order are drainage improvements necessary to improve poor drainage surrounding the football field in the amount of $13,404, for a net change of ($27,596).
	 
Total Change Orders to date for this project are in the amount of ($27,596), or, (3.46%) of the original contract.  The original agreement amount is $797,850.  The new contract value including this change order will be $770,254.
	 
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of a Prime Contract Change Order OC Jones & Sons Inc. in the amount of ($27,596) for the SJCC Track & Field Project.
	 
	 
Revision 1 – Marcy Wong Donn Logan Architects - SJCC New Theater & Votech - Temporary Fitness Center Housing
	 
Construction of the new Performing Arts Center requires Building 300 to be demolished and therefore temporary space for the Fitness Center will be required until it can be relocated to its permanent home in the new Gym Building. This sub-project is being integrated with the SJCC New Theater & Votech project. This revision to Marcy Wong Donn Logan Architects in the amount of $84,993 includes the necessary services to design and administer the construction of the temporary facility noted above (approximately 8,000 SF).  The original agreement amount is $201,777.  The new contract value including this revision will be $286,770.   
	 
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of Revision 1 to Marcy Wong Donn Logan Architecture in the amount of $84,993 for design and construction administration services for the SJCC New Theater & Votech – Temporary Fitness Center Housing.

Education Code Section 81335 allows California Community Colleges to utilize the Lease-Lease back project delivery method for new construction projects. The Project Management Team presented information to the Board on alternative project delivery methods, including Lease-Lease Back, on March 13, 2012 and June 12, 2012. The Board approved an action item on July 10, 2010 authorizing the use of the Lease-Lease Back project delivery method for two Measure G-2010 projects, the San Jose City College New Theater and Vocational Technology project and the Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development project. 
	 
This resolution is required for the Validation Action legal process noted in the resolution. The Validation Action process is intended to protect the Districtâs interests in the Lease-Lease Back project delivery method and is only required for the first project. For this reason, this resolution has been prepared for only the San Jose City College New Theater and Vocational Technology project.  At a later date the Board will approve by Resolution the selection of the best qualified contractor chosen and that will be referenced in the court papers.  Each successive Lease-Lease Back project will require board approval, but we will not be filing any further court validation actions.

As has been discussed with the Board previously, the Acacia and Roble complexes are located within a seismic fault zone that was recently determined to be active.  As required by law, the District notified the State Chancellor's Office of this issue in October 2011 and has been actively engaged in the planning activities that will result in the removal and replacement of these buildings out of the fault zone.  
	 
The space provided by the Acacia and Roble complexes will be replaced under three projects currently represented on the Measure G-2010 Bond Project List: South Campus Development, Automotive Technology and Engineering & Applied Technology. The District does, however, have the opportunity to apply to the State for funding support for a component of this program due to the seismic issue.  As such, an Initial Project Proposal (IPP) for Acacia - Roble Replacement (Engineering & Applied Technology) for the 2015 funding year has been prepared by HMC Architects for submission to the State Chancellor's Office.  This project proposal requests the State to support 50% of the budget for the demolition and replacement of space represented by the project referred to as Engineering & Applied Technology on the Measure G-2010 Master Bond Project List.

items.item_details:
California Education Code 82537-48 allows the governing board of any community college district to grant the use of college facilities or grounds for public, literary, scientific, recreational, educational, or public agency meetings.  The use of any community college facility and grounds for any meeting is subject to reasonable rules and regulations as the governing board of the district prescribes, and shall not interfere with the use and occupancy of the community college facilities and grounds, as is required for the purposes of the community colleges of the state.  The governing board of the community college district shall make all needful rules and regulations for conducting the civic meetings and for such recreational activities as are provided for within the code and which aid, assist, and lend encouragement to the activities.
	 
The governing board may charge non-profit organizations, clubs, and associations organized for general character building or welfare purposes an amount not to exceed direct costs defined as the cost of opening and closing the facilities, the cost of a college employee's presence during the use of the facilities, the cost of janitorial services, and the cost of utilities attributable to the use of the facilities.
	 
The governing board may charge organizations not listed above an amount not to exceed direct costs defined as supplies, utilities, janitorial services, services of any other district employees, and salaries paid to district employees necessitated by the organization's use of the colleges' facilities or grounds; or not to exceed fair rental value of the facilities and grounds of the colleges.
	 
Attached are the proposed fees for San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College for consideration for approval by the Board of Trustees.

San Jose City College wishes to establish an agreement to continue to partner with Saint Elizabeth's Day Home, a California nonprofit charitable public benefit corporation (hereinafter "Sub-Contractor").  San Jose City College has found the Sub-Contractor able to meet the needs of the Child Development Division, California Department of Education (CDC) for state child development program services for both Toddler and Preschool care.
	 
As the certified CDD contractor, SJCC will continue to conduct fiscal agent responsibilities and compliance checks to meet the condition of its contract with the California Department of Education, Child Development Division and to adhere to the Funding Terms and Conditions (FT&C).
